reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient accidentally discovered bilateral neck masses one month ago, which were about the size of a walnut. He did not feel any difficulty breathing or swallowing, and there was no foreign body sensation in the anterior neck or neck edema. There were no symptoms of hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism, such as heat intolerance, sweating, polyphagia, hunger, irritability, poor appetite, weight loss, hoarseness, or ptosis. His living habits such as diet, sleep, and urination were normal. He had not received any treatment. Color Doppler ultrasound examination at an external hospital showed mixed nodules and internal cystic nodules in both lobes of the thyroid gland, and no abnormalities were found in the cervical lymph nodes. The patient came to our hospital for further diagnosis and treatment. The outpatient diagnosis was "bilateral thyroid tumors" and he was admitted to the hospital.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
Thyroid color ultrasound:
- Mixed nodules in both thyroid lobes, TI-RADS classification: Category 3
- Intrathyroid cystic nodule, TI-RADS classification: Category 2
- No obvious abnormal lymph nodes were found on both sides of the neck
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Bilateral nodular goiter
2. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
reference_diagnosis.basis: A middle-aged woman has been diagnosed with a thyroid tumor for more than a month. Physical examination revealed bilateral thyroid tumors, approximately 3.5cm × 3.0cm in size, with clear boundaries, smooth surface, medium texture, and no tenderness. They could move up and down with swallowing, and no vascular murmur was heard.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: The patient completed relevant examinations after admission and found no contraindications to surgery. Bilateral subtotal thyroidectomy was performed under cervical plexus block anesthesia. Shortness of breath, cyanosis, increased heart rate, and chest X-ray showed pulmonary edema after surgery. Consider ARDS, perform endotracheal intubation immediately, assist ventilation, and administer dopamine, albumin, plasma, adrenocortical hormones, and antibiotics. His condition stabilized after 24 hours, and he recovered and was discharged from the hospital half a month later.

reference_diagnosis.basis:

reference_diagnosis.treatment: After admission, he was given acid-suppressing, stomach-protecting, anti-inflammatory, and hypoglycemic treatments. Complete electrocardiogram, blood routine, blood biochemistry, tumor markers, chest CT, abdominal CT, gastrointestinal endoscopy and other examinations. Chest CT and whole-abdominal CT showed high-density shadows in both lungs, but no other abnormalities were found. Gastroscopy revealed esophageal ulcers and proliferative bulges in the gastric antrum mucosa, but no abnormalities were found in colonoscopy. The patient later developed nausea, vomiting, and edema of both lower limbs. A reexamination of liver function revealed hypoalbuminemia, and renal function examination revealed renal insufficiency. After consultation with the nephrology department, it was recommended to complete the detection of urinary Binder protein and anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies. The patient was later transferred to a higher-level hospital for treatment and was diagnosed with ANCA-associated vasculitis.

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
#Symptoms#

(1) Upper abdominal pain for the past half month, mostly at night
(2) Anorexia without obvious cause for two months
(3) Occasionally coughing up white sputum

#Auxiliary Examinations#

(1) Blood tests to check for infection, inflammation, and liver function
(2) Abdominal ultrasound to check for gallstones or other abnormalities
(3) Upper endoscopy to check for ulcers or inflammation in the stomach or esophagus
(4) HbA1c test to check for blood sugar control
(5) Chest X-ray to check for bronchiectasis exacerbation

#Diagnosis#

Based on the patient's symptoms and medical history, the most likely diagnosis is Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

#Diagnostic Basis#

(1) The patient's symptoms of upper abdominal pain, anorexia, and occasionally coughing up white sputum are consistent with GERD.
(2) The patient's history of type 2 diabetes and irregular use of acarbose and Xiaoke Pills may contribute to the development of GERD.
(3) The patient's history of bronchiectasis may also contribute to the development of GERD.

#Treatment Plan#

(1) Lifestyle modifications, such as avoiding trigger foods, eating smaller meals, and not lying down after eating, can help reduce symptoms of GERD.
(2) Medications, such as proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) or H2 blockers, can help reduce stomach acid production and relieve symptoms of GERD.
(3) If lifestyle modifications and medications are not effective, surgery may be considered to strengthen the lower esophageal sphincter and prevent stomach acid from flowing back into the esophagus.
(4) The patient should also continue to manage their type 2 diabetes and bronchiectasis with appropriate medications and lifestyle modifications.

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient reported that he had developed chest tightness and shortness of breath more than 10 years ago after exertion or emotional excitement, which were relieved after resting. He had been hospitalized many times due to "coronary heart disease and angina pectoris". He took medications such as Coronary Salvia Miltiorrhiza Tablets and Aspirin Enteric-coated Tablets, but his condition did not improve significantly. In the past four days, the symptoms have worsened, accompanied by edema of both lower limbs, without chest pain or wheezing, and he can lie down at night. The symptoms were not relieved after taking Guanxin Danshen Tablets and other drugs orally, so he was hospitalized for treatment.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- Electrocardiogram
- Sinus rhythm, heart rate 79 beats/min
- ST segment depression and flat T wave in leads II, III, and aVF
- Cardiac ultrasound
- Moderate aortic regurgitation
- Small amounts of mitral, tricuspid, and pulmonary regurgitation
- Decreased left ventricular diastolic function
- Left ventricular ejection fraction 58%
- Chest X-ray
- Aortic sclerosis
- Coronary artery calcification
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Coronary atherosclerotic heart disease, ischemic cardiomyopathy, heart failure, cardiac function class III
2. neurasthenia
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. The patient has symptoms of long-term chest tightness and shortness of breath, accompanied by a history of neurasthenia.
2. The symptoms of chest tightness and shortness of breath have recently worsened, accompanied by edema of both lower limbs. There is no chest pain or wheezing, and the patient can lie down at night.
3. Physical examination revealed mild cyanosis of the lips, a heart rate of 79 beats/min, a regular heart rate, and no pathological murmur.
4. Auxiliary examination showed abnormal electrocardiogram, cardiac ultrasound showed valvular regurgitation and reduced left ventricular diastolic function, and chest X-ray showed aortic and coronary artery sclerosis.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: A comprehensive auxiliary examination will be performed after admission. Implement routine care for circulatory system diseases, Level I care, low-salt and low-fat diet, continuous low-flow oxygen inhalation, and monitor ECG and blood oxygen. Administer aspirin enteric-coated capsules, atorvastatin calcium tablets, ** tablets, spironolactone tablets, metoprolol tablets, enalapril tablets, ** tablets for oral administration, intravenous infusion of Danhong injection, and isosorbide mononitrate The ester is continuously pumped in. Regularly review the electrocardiogram.

(4) Blood tests to evaluate kidney function and electrolyte levels

#Diagnosis#
Congestive heart failure

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) History of coronary heart disease and angina pectoris
(2) Symptoms of chest tightness, shortness of breath, and edema in lower limbs
(3) Abnormal results from ECG, echocardiogram, and chest X-ray
(4) Abnormal blood test results indicating impaired kidney function and electrolyte imbalance

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Medications to improve heart function and reduce fluid buildup, such as diuretics, ACE inhibitors, and beta-blockers
(2) Lifestyle modifications, such as a low-sodium diet, regular exercise, and weight management
(3) Regular follow-up appointments with a cardiologist to monitor heart function and adjust treatment as needed
(4) Referral to a cardiac rehabilitation program to improve physical fitness and reduce the risk of future heart problems.

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient developed fever after catching cold due to exertion, with the highest temperature reaching 39°C, accompanied by fatigue, myalgia, cough, and sputum production. She was treated with cephalosporin antibiotics at a local clinic, but her symptoms were not relieved. The condition gradually worsened, with chest tightness, shortness of breath and difficulty breathing. Outpatient chest CT showed bilateral lung infection and nodular lesions, and he was subsequently admitted to the hospital.

reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Sheep brucellosis
2. Tuberculosis and lung infection
3. Liver damage
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. Personal history: Engaged in sheep slaughtering and selling sheep braised products.
2. Symptoms: Fever, fatigue for more than 10 days, shortness of breath, and dyspnea for 5 days.
3. Physical signs: clear mind, poor energy, thick breath sounds in both lungs, and phlegm sounds.
4. Auxiliary examination: ESR 72mm/h, abnormal liver function, growth of Brucella in blood culture, positive tuberculosis gamma interferon release test, chest CT showed bilateral lung infection and nodular lesions.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After admission, the patient received anti-infective treatment, phlegm-reducing treatment, hepatoprotective treatment and nutritional support treatment. The condition did not improve, and brucellosis was considered. Blood culture and antibody tests were both positive. After one week of treatment, his condition did not improve. Further examination revealed that the tuberculosis gamma interferon release test was positive, and he was diagnosed as pulmonary tuberculosis infection. After additional treatment with anti-tuberculosis drugs, the body temperature dropped, the erythrocyte sedimentation rate dropped, and the patient was discharged after his condition became stable.

reference_diagnosis.basis: A middle-aged male patient was admitted to the hospital because of chest tightness and nausea for 2 days, which worsened for 1.5 hours. She was accompanied by abdominal distension, nausea, and precordial discomfort, and the electrocardiogram showed low and flat T waves in multiple leads. The hemoglobin dropped to 63g/L, the stool was positive for occult blood, and melena appeared recently. Long-term oral aspirin may cause upper gastrointestinal bleeding. Precordial discomfort may result from angina due to cardiac hypoperfusion due to anemia.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: The patient was transferred from the cardiology department to the gastroenterology department and given NS50ml + esomeprazole 80mg by continuous pumping. The hemoglobin dropped to 57g/L, and 2 units of red blood cells were transfused. Monitor vital signs and provide fluid rehydration and nutritional support. After the condition stabilized, a gastroscopy was performed and duodenal bulb ulcer (stage S1) was found.

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient developed right limb weakness 1 year ago and was diagnosed with cerebral infarction. After treatment, the patient still had limb weakness and could walk with crutches. One day before admission, he developed left limb weakness without obvious triggers. The symptoms worsened after resting. He is currently unable to walk upright and has slow reactions, but he can communicate briefly through speech.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- Film degree exam
  - Plain head CT scan: multiple patchy and flaky low-density shadows with blurred edges and no obvious edema or mass effect were seen in the bilateral lateral ventricles, right occipital lobe, left centrum semiovale and parietal lobe. The ventricular system was normal, there was no obvious widening or narrowing of the sulci, fissures, and cisterns, the midline structure was centered, and there were no abnormalities in the cerebellar hemispheres.
- Laboratory tests
  - Random blood sugar: 17.6mmol/L
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: Cerebral infarction; type 2 diabetes; sequelae of cerebral infarction; carotid arteriosclerosis
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. Medical history: Type 2 diabetes for more than 10 years, irregular medication, and a history of cerebral infarction.
2. Symptoms: Right limb weakness for 1 year and left limb weakness for 1 day.
3. Physical signs: blood pressure 162/86mmHg, clear consciousness, unresponsiveness, clear breath sounds in both lungs, strong and regular heart sounds, and no murmurs. The muscle tone of the limbs was low, the muscle strength of the left limb was grade 0, and the muscle strength of the right limb was grade 1. Babinski sign was positive bilaterally.
4. Auxiliary examination: random blood sugar 17.6mmol/L. Head CT scan showed multiple low-density shadows without edema or mass effect.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After being admitted to hospital, the patient missed the opportunity for intravenous thrombolysis and was given oral aspirin enteric-coated tablets for antithrombotic therapy, intravenous infusion of citicoline sodium for brain protection, and blood sugar adjustment. The limbs were positioned to prevent contracture, and rehabilitation training was started the next day. After being hospitalized for 2 weeks, he was discharged. The muscle strength of his left lower limb improved to level 3, and the muscle strength of his left upper limb improved to level 1. He could support the bed and stand.

#Symptoms#
(1) Edema in both lower limbs, more severe on the left side, for about a month.
(2) Pain in the left lower limb.
(3) Cough with yellow phlegm and chest tightness for 17 days, worsening after physical activity.
(4) Chronic irritating cough for over 30 years.
(5) Previously diagnosed with coronary heart disease and acute bronchitis.

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Chest X-ray to evaluate lungs and heart.
(2) Pulmonary function tests to assess lung function.
(3) Echocardiogram to evaluate heart function.
(4) Doppler ultrasound to evaluate blood flow in lower limbs.

#Diagnosis#
(1) Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
(2) Congestive heart failure (CHF)

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Chronic irritating cough for over 30 years, worsening symptoms with yellow phlegm, and chest tightness.
(2) Edema in both lower limbs, more severe on the left side, and pain in the left lower limb.
(3) Previous diagnosis of coronary heart disease and acute bronchitis.
(4) Chest X-ray, pulmonary function tests, echocardiogram, and Doppler ultrasound results.

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Bronchodilators and inhaled corticosteroids for COPD management.
(2) Diuretics, ACE inhibitors, and beta-blockers for CHF management.
(3) Regular follow-ups with a cardiologist and pulmonologist.
(4) Lifestyle modifications, including smoking cessation, regular exercise, and a heart-healthy diet.
(5) Vaccinations for influenza and pneumococcal pneumonia.
(6) Pulmonary rehabilitation program to improve lung function and overall health.

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient developed cough, sputum, and wheezing after catching a cold 7 years ago. The symptoms worsened every winter and were relieved in spring. The symptoms lasted for more than 3 months each year. I went to the doctor many times and was diagnosed with chronic bronchitis and emphysema, but the treatment was not effective. In the past two days, the symptoms worsened due to a cold. He coughed up yellowish-white sticky sputum without blood sputum, had a fever of 38.6°C, and had no chills. He took cephalexin tablets, powerful loquat dew and other drugs orally, but the symptoms were not relieved, so he was admitted to the hospital.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- Pulmonary imaging examination
  - Lung CT: chronic bronchitis combined with emphysema and aortic sclerosis.
- blood test
  - Blood routine: white blood cells 12.3×10^9/L, neutrophil percentage 85%.
- Bone and joint examination
  - Left knee radiograph: knee arthritis.
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Chronic bronchitis
2. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease combined with infection
3. Knee arthritis
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. A 7-year history of cough, sputum production, and wheezing, and a 10-year history of bilateral knee arthritis.
2. Current symptoms: worsening cough, coughing up a large amount of yellowish-white sticky sputum, no bloody sputum, wheezing, no dyspnea, able to lie down at night, fever to 38.6°C, no chills.
3. Physical examination: Barrel-shaped chest, symmetrical chest, consistent respiratory movements, weakened tremor, voiceless percussion of both lungs, weak breath sounds, and full of wheezing.
4. Auxiliary examination: Lung CT showed chronic bronchitis combined with emphysema and aortic sclerosis; blood routine white blood cells increased and the percentage of neutrophils increased; left knee joint radiograph showed knee arthritis.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After admission, auxiliary examinations were performed, and the patient was given routine nursing care in the rehabilitation department, level I nursing care, liquid food, and continuous low-flow oxygen inhalation. Treatment includes theophylline sustained-release tablets, terbutaline for intravenous asthma relief, compound licorice tablets, eucalyptus and lemon pine capsules for oral administration, ambroxol injection for intravenous cough and phlegm reduction, cefoperazone and sulbactam for intravenous anti-infection, Protease aerosol inhalation relieves wheezing, and Kuabi capsules are taken orally to relax muscles and relieve pain.

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient had intermittent cough without obvious triggers one month ago, accompanied by a small amount of white sticky sputum, and was not accompanied by symptoms such as fever, nasal congestion, runny nose, chest tightness, chest pain, asthma or fatigue. Oral medication at the local clinic was not effective. In the past three days, the cough has worsened and the amount of sputum has increased, accompanied by intermittent high fever, with the maximum body temperature reaching 39.0°C. After antipyretic and anti-infective treatments were given by the local clinic, the symptoms did not improve and the fever recurred, so he came to our hospital for treatment. Since the onset of the disease, his energy, diet, and sleep have been normal, his physical strength has declined, and he has lost about 20 pounds in weight.

reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Tuberculosis and lung infection
2. Chronic hepatitis B virus
3. Diabetes
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. Symptoms: intermittent cough for 1 month, worsening with fever for 3 days.
2. Signs: Chronic liver disease, thick breath sounds in both lungs, and rales can be heard in the left lung.
3. Auxiliary examination: elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, elevated blood sugar, positive acid-fast staining of sputum, positive hepatitis B related indicators, chest CT showed left pneumonia.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: The patient underwent comprehensive auxiliary examinations after admission, and the sputum test was positive and confirmed to be pulmonary tuberculosis. Anti-infective treatment with ceftazidime, phlegm-reducing treatment with ambroxol, hepatoprotective treatment with reduced glutathione, and anti-tuberculosis drugs (rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, ethambutol, and levofloxacin) were given. At the same time, anti-hepatitis B virus treatment with tenofovir and hypoglycemic treatment with metformin and acarbose were given. After half a month, his condition stabilized and he was discharged from the hospital and continued oral medication.

Based on the information provided, I would like to consider the following differential diagnoses:

1. Bacterial pneumonia
2. Viral pneumonia
3. Tuberculosis
4. Lung cancer
5. Bronchitis
6. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)

Based on the results of the chest X-ray and blood tests, I would like to rule out bacterial pneumonia as a possible diagnosis. However, I would like to wait for the results of the sputum culture before making a definitive diagnosis.

(2) The blood tests indicate an increase in white blood cells, which is consistent with an infection.
(3) The sputum culture is still pending, but it will help us determine if the infection is bacterial or viral.

#Treatment Plan#
(1) I would recommend starting the patient on a course of antibiotics to treat the bacterial infection.
(2) I would also recommend that the patient rest and stay hydrated to help their body fight off the infection.
(3) Once we receive the results of the sputum culture, I will be able to provide a more specific diagnosis and treatment plan. If the sputum culture is negative for bacteria, we may need to consider other possible diagnoses such as viral pneumonia, tuberculosis, lung cancer, bronchitis, or COPD.

Please feel free to ask any questions or provide additional details that may help me better understand your condition. I am here to help you and ensure that you receive the best possible care.

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient reported that he began to experience fatigue and weakness 2 years ago, and his symptoms gradually worsened. During this period, no skin purpura, fever, chills, bleeding symptoms (gum bleeding, nose bleeding, blood in urine or stool), nausea, vomiting, headache, dizziness, etc. occurred. He was diagnosed with "essential thrombocythemia" in a local tertiary hospital. He received interferon injections and oral medication, and his symptoms improved. In the past half month, bright red bleeding occurred after defecation, about 30 ml each time, and stopped on its own without constipation or diarrhea. He came to our hospital for further diagnosis and treatment. He was diagnosed as "essential thrombocythemia and mixed hemorrhoids" in the outpatient department and was admitted to the hospital.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- Blood routine:
  - White blood cell count: 8.5*10^9/L
  - Neutrophil ratio: 61.60%
  - Lymphocyte ratio: 31.3%
  - Number of neutrophils: 5.23*10^9/L
  -Number of lymphocytes: 2.66*10^9/L
  - Number of monocytes: 0.54*10^9/L
  - Eosinophil count: 0.09*10^9/L
  - Red blood cell count: 3.68*10^12/L
  - Hemoglobin: 119g/L
  - Hematocrit: 34.8%
  - Platelet count: 651*10^9/L
  - Platelet density: 0.454%
- Coagulation:
  - Prothrombin time: 11.2 seconds
  - International normalized ratio: 0.89
  - Partially activated prothrombin time: 30.3 seconds
  - Fibrinogen: 2.67g/L
  - Thrombin time: 15.3 seconds
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Essential thrombocythemia
2. Mixed hemorrhoids
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. A middle-aged woman with chronic onset, long-term fatigue and weakness.
2. Diagnosed with essential thrombocythemia 2 years ago, symptoms improved after treatment.
3. Recently, bright red bleeding after defecation stopped on its own.
4. Skin tags were found during perianal examination, but no tumors were felt during rectal examination.
5. Routine blood test showed a significant increase in platelet count.
6. Coagulation function test results were basically normal.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After admission, the patient underwent a comprehensive examination and was given traditional Chinese medicine fumigation, topical hemorrhoid ointment and hemorrhoid suppository treatment, as well as hemostatic drugs. As post-defecation bleeding persisted and conservative treatment was ineffective, surgical treatment was decided. Under spinal anesthesia, hemorrhoid internal ligation and external removal, anal sphincter dilation and hemorrhoid injection were performed. Postoperative bleeding stopped and the patient recovered and was discharged.

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient developed dizziness and nausea on July 24, and her symptoms were relieved after taking Huoxiang Zhengqi capsules by herself. On July 29, he developed fatigue, asthma, and edema in both feet. He was diagnosed at Jincheng People's Hospital as chronic renal failure (uremic stage), acute left heart failure, renal anemia, hyperkalemia, and grade 3 hypertension. After receiving femoral vein catheterization and regular hemodialysis treatment, his condition improved. On August 12, arteriovenous fistula surgery was performed on the left upper limb. After his condition stabilized, he was transferred to our hospital for continued treatment.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- Blood routine
  - Hemoglobin: 115g/L
  - Platelets: 185×10^9/L
- Biochemical tests
  - Urea: 24.09mmol/L
  - Uric acid: 517.0umol/L
  - Creatinine: 810umol/L
  - Albumin: 38.5g/L
- Echocardiography
  - Enlargement of left atrium
  - Mitral regurgitation
  - Aortic regurgitation
  - Symmetrical thickening of the interventricular septum and left ventricular posterior wall
  - Reduced left ventricular diastolic function
- Color Doppler Ultrasound of Lower Limb Veins
  - Incomplete thrombotic occlusion of the right external iliac vein and common femoral vein of the right lower limb
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Uremic stage of chronic renal failure; renal anemia with regular hemodialysis
2. Hypertension grade 3 extremely high risk
3. Left upper limb arteriovenous fistula surgery
4. Incomplete thrombotic occlusion of the external iliac vein and common femoral vein of the right lower limb
reference_diagnosis.basis: Combined with medical history, symptoms and auxiliary examination results, including blood routine, biochemical examination, cardiac color ultrasound and lower limb venous color ultrasound.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After admission, he was given drug treatments such as lercanidipine, arollol, Bailing capsules, compound ketoacid tablets, and ferrous succinate to maintain hemodialysis. The patient's symptoms gradually improved, his spirit and appetite improved, and the edema of his lower limbs was reduced. Temporary tube embolism occurred many times during dialysis, but dialysis was successful after urokinase thrombolysis. On August 24, the temporary femoral vein catheter was removed and compression was used to stop the bleeding. Swelling of the right lower limb occurred on the night of August 27. On the morning of the 28th, color ultrasound of the lower limb blood vessels confirmed thrombotic occlusion. It was recommended to transfer to a higher-level hospital for lower limb venous filter and thrombolysis. His condition is currently stable and hemodialysis continues.

(3) The patient's history of femoral vein catheterization and regular hemodialysis, along with the symptoms of dizziness and nausea, supports the diagnosis of chronic renal failure and renal anemia.
(4) The patient's history of arteriovenous fistula surgery on the left upper limb supports the diagnosis of chronic renal failure.

#Treatment Plan#

(2) Prescribe medications to manage hypertension and heart failure, such as ACE inhibitors, beta-blockers, and diuretics.
(3) Recommend a low-sodium, low-potassium diet to manage hyperkalemia.
(4) Encourage regular exercise and weight management to improve overall health and manage hypertension.
(5) Monitor the patient's blood pressure, electrolyte levels, and kidney function regularly to adjust the treatment plan as needed.

Since the onset of the disease, there has been no headache, fever, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, tinnitus, visual rotation, or respiratory or digestive system symptoms. The patient's mental state and appetite were good, defecation was normal, and the frequency of urination increased.

3. Physical signs: Body temperature 36.0°C, pulse 64 beats/min, respiration 20 times/min, blood pressure 160/98mmHg, clear mind, fluent speech, decreased memory, calculation ability, and understanding, normal rough visual field test, and free eye movement. The facial sensation was symmetrical, the limb muscle strength was level 5, the allodynia was reduced, and the meningeal irritation sign was negative.
4. Auxiliary examination: blood sugar 6.1mmol/L, electrocardiogram abnormality, cervical vascular ultrasound showed plaque, cardiac ultrasound showed reduced left ventricular diastolic function, abdominal ultrasound showed right renal cyst, and head CT showed lacunar cerebral infarction.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: Dual antiplatelet aggregation therapy was given to improve circulation, regulate blood pressure, brain protection, and statin therapy. After 10 days of hospitalization, the patient had no episodic limb weakness and his blood pressure was well controlled.

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient was found to have bilateral thyroid masses through color ultrasound one year ago, with the left side being larger and painless. There were no other symptoms of hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism. Recently, the mass on the left side of the neck has increased. Color ultrasound showed that the left lobe of the thyroid gland is occupying space, which is considered malignant. The cervical lymph nodes are swollen and partially calcified. The neck mass was punctured and dark red fluid was aspirated, and a biopsy was recommended. The patient's general condition is good and there is no obvious weight loss.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- Color ultrasound examination
  - Space-occupying left thyroid lobe with sandy calcification, TI-RADS category IV C
  - Multiple swollen lymph nodes on the left side of the neck with some calcifications
  - Right thyroid lobe nodule, TI-RADS category III
- Fine needle aspiration
  - 2 ml of dark red liquid was aspirated, and scattered epithelial cells were seen. The possibility of thyroid follicular epithelium was considered, and nuclear grooves were visible in some parts.
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: Left thyroid gland cancer (T2N1M0), right benign nodule.
reference_diagnosis.basis: Based on the medical history, physical examination and auxiliary examination results, it is considered that the left lobe of the thyroid gland may be malignant and the right lobe nodule may be benign. Intraoperative rapid pathology showed thyroid cancer on the left side and no clear tumor tissue on the right side. Paraffin pathology further confirmed that the left thyroid gland had ovarian cancer, with a mass size of 2cm × 2cm × 1cm, and tumor tissue metastasis in the left central area and cervical lymph nodes. The right thyroid gland is an adenoma.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After admission, the patient completed relevant examinations, including blood routine, thyroid function, liver and kidney function, blood sugar, electrolytes, coagulation function, electrocardiogram, chest X-ray, etc. No abnormalities were found. CT neck showed space occupying the left lobe of the thyroid gland and enlarged lymph nodes in the left neck. Preoperative preparation was sufficient, and left thyroid lobe + isthmus resection + right subtotal thyroidectomy was performed. The patient recovered well after the operation and was given fluids, electrolytes and hemostatic treatment. The sutures were removed and discharged after 10 days of hospitalization.

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
#Symptoms#
(1) A mass on the left side of the thyroid that has been present for about a year and has recently grown larger.
(2) No other symptoms of hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism.

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Color ultrasound showed bilateral thyroid masses, with the left side being larger and painless. The left lobe of the thyroid gland is occupying space, which is considered malignant. The cervical lymph nodes are swollen and partially calcified.
(2) The neck mass was punctured and dark red fluid was aspirated, and a biopsy was recommended.

#Diagnosis#
Thyroid cancer

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) The presence of a mass on the thyroid that has grown larger over time.
(2) The results of the color ultrasound and the aspiration of dark red fluid from the neck mass.

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Fine needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy to determine if the thyroid mass is benign or malignant.
(2) If the biopsy confirms thyroid cancer, surgery to remove the thyroid gland and any affected lymph nodes will be recommended.
(3) Radioactive iodine therapy may be recommended after surgery to destroy any remaining thyroid tissue and prevent the cancer from returning.
(4) Regular follow-up appointments and thyroid function tests will be necessary to monitor for any recurrence of the cancer.

(5) History of gallbladder stones for more than 10 years, treated with medication intermittently

#Auxiliary Examinations#

(1) Blood tests to check for signs of infection or inflammation
(2) Abdominal ultrasound to check for gallstones or other abnormalities in the gallbladder or bile ducts
(3) CT scan of the abdomen to check for any other abnormalities or blockages in the abdomen
(4) Endoscopy to check for any abnormalities in the stomach or esophagus

#Diagnosis#

Acute cholecystitis

#Diagnostic Basis#

(1) The patient's symptoms of epigastric pain, nausea, and vomiting, along with the pain radiating to the left ribs and waist, are consistent with acute cholecystitis.
(2) The patient's history of gallbladder stones for more than 10 years increases the likelihood of acute cholecystitis.
(3) The results of the abdominal ultrasound and CT scan will help confirm the diagnosis.

#Treatment Plan#

(1) Hospitalization for intravenous fluids, pain management, and antibiotics
(2) Surgical removal of the gallbladder (cholecystectomy) may be necessary if the patient's symptoms do not improve with conservative treatment.
(3) Avoidance of greasy or fatty foods and taking over-the-counter pain relievers as needed for pain management.
(4) Follow-up with a gastroenterologist or surgeon for further management and monitoring.

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient had chest tightness without obvious triggers 3 days ago, which was moderate and irregular, lasting about 2 minutes each time, accompanied by abdominal discomfort and loose stools. No chills, cyanosis, shortness of breath, chest pain, palpitations, abdominal pain or diarrhea. He sought medical treatment and was diagnosed with "abnormal cardiac enzymes" and was admitted to the hospital for further diagnosis and treatment. Since the onset of the disease, his energy and appetite have decreased, his sleep is normal, and his bowel movements are normal.

  - Chlorine: 95.2 mmol/L↓
- Blood lipids:
  - HDL cholesterol: 0.49 mmol/L↓
  - LDL cholesterol: 1.53 mmol/L↓
- Chlamydia pneumoniae antibody (CPN-IgG): Positive↑

reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: Lobar pneumonia
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. A 67-year-old man suffered from chest tightness and abdominal discomfort for 3 days.
2. Physical examination: Respiration in both lungs is weakened, no rales are heard; heart sounds are completely free of murmurs; the abdomen is soft, without tenderness or rebound tenderness, and bowel sounds are slightly active.
3. Auxiliary examination supports diagnosis.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: The patient's body temperature returned to normal after admission, and he is now asymptomatic, with cough and sputum accompanied by fatigue and loss of appetite. Physical examination revealed reduced breathing in both lungs and a small amount of wheezing in both lower lungs. Auxiliary examination showed elevated white blood cells and electrolyte imbalance. Chest CT showed exudative lesions in the right lung, suggesting interstitial inflammation and right lower lung infection. Treatment includes anti-infection and antipyretic treatments. After 12 days of hospitalization, the symptoms improved and the inflammatory lesions dissipated.

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
#Symptoms#
(1) Chest tightness and abdominal discomfort for the past three days
(2) Decreased energy and appetite

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Electrocardiogram (ECG) to check for any abnormalities in heart rhythm and electrical activity
(2) Blood tests to check for any abnormalities in cardiac enzymes, electrolytes, and other markers of heart function
(3) Chest X-ray to check for any abnormalities in the heart and lungs
(4) Abdominal ultrasound to check for any abnormalities in abdominal organs

#Diagnosis#
Acute coronary syndrome (ACS)

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Symptoms of chest tightness and abdominal discomfort
(2) Abnormal cardiac enzymes
(3) ECG findings suggestive of ischemia or infarction
(4) Chest X-ray and abdominal ultrasound to rule out other causes of symptoms

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Admission to the hospital for further monitoring and management
(2) Medications such as aspirin, clopidogrel, and anticoagulants to prevent further clot formation
(3) Nitroglycerin to relieve chest pain and improve blood flow to the heart
(4) Pain management with medications such as morphine or fentanyl
(5) Cardiac catheterization and possible intervention such as angioplasty or stent placement to restore blood flow to the heart
(6) Lifestyle modifications such as smoking cessation, dietary changes, and exercise to reduce the risk of future cardiac events.

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient developed right-sided chest pain without obvious triggers, accompanied by dry cough. The symptoms worsened when coughing and taking deep breaths. Low fever occurred, with a maximum body temperature of 37.9°C. Fever occurred in the afternoon, and the body temperature was normal in the morning. No chills, fever, or sweating. He went to a local hospital and was diagnosed with "pneumonia". He received intravenous infusion treatment, but the symptoms were not relieved. A week ago, I developed dyspnea and chest tightness, accompanied by fatigue, night sweats, and loss of appetite. The chest pain was relieved, but the cough was not relieved. Therefore, he came to our hospital for treatment. He was diagnosed as "pleural effusion" in the outpatient department and was admitted to the hospital.

4. Chest X-ray showed a large amount of pleural effusion on the right side.

Stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA)

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Sudden onset of weakness in the right limb and slurred speech
(2) Absence of bleeding on head CT
(3) History of intermittent hypertension, which is a risk factor for stroke

#Treatment Plan#

(3) Blood tests, including a complete blood count (CBC), electrolytes, and glucose levels, to rule out other causes of symptoms
(4) Lumbar puncture (spinal tap) to rule out infection or inflammation
(5) Carotid ultrasound to evaluate for carotid artery disease
(6) Medications to manage blood pressure and prevent further strokes
(7) Rehabilitation therapy to improve strength and function in the affected limb and speech therapy to address any communication difficulties.

#Symptoms#
(1) Paroxysmal limb twitching for the past 14 days
(2) Tonic twitching of limbs during sleep, accompanied by foaming at the mouth and loss of consciousness, lasting for about 1 minute
(3) Confusion, gibbering, and irritability after convulsions
(4) Headache symptoms after convulsions
(5) Fever and headache 16 days ago, with the highest temperature of 37.8°C
(6) Positive test for the new coronavirus

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Brain MRI showed abnormal signals in the left frontal lobe

#Diagnosis#
Viral encephalitis secondary to COVID-19 infection

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Symptoms of fever, headache, and altered mental status
(2) Positive test for the new coronavirus
(3) Abnormal brain MRI findings

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Admit the patient to the hospital for close monitoring and supportive care
(2) Antiviral therapy with remdesivir or other appropriate antiviral medication
(3) Intracranial pressure-lowering treatment with mannitol or other appropriate medication
(4) Antiepileptic medication to control seizures
(5) Blood pressure management with telmisartan 40mg daily
(6) Repeat brain MRI in 2-4 weeks to monitor for any changes in the brain abnormalities
(7) Consider lumbar puncture to rule out other causes of altered mental status, such as bacterial meningitis or cerebral vasculitis
(8) Consider electroencephalogram (EEG) to confirm seizure disorder
(9) Consider blood tests to rule out other causes of seizures, such as electrolyte imbalances or infections
(10) Provide supportive care, such as hydration, nutrition, and pain management, as needed.

In the past 5 days, the difficulty in breathing has gradually worsened, and I wake up at night. There is no fever, runny nose, muscle and joint pain, nausea and vomiting, diarrhea, dizziness, headache, or chest pain. Emergency SPO2: 70%. After lung CT and COVID-19 nucleic acid testing, he was admitted to the emergency buffer ward with "heart failure". Since the onset of the disease, he has had poor appetite, poor energy, poor sleep, no abnormalities in urination and defecation, and no significant changes in weight.

  - Bilateral pleural thickening
  - Increased heart shadow
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Heart failure: cardiac function class IV
2. Lung infection
3. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease accompanied by acute exacerbation
4. Electrolyte metabolism disorders: hyponatremia, hypochloremia
5. Hypoalbuminemia
6. Abnormal myocardial enzyme profile
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. Dyspnea accompanied by cough and sputum for more than 20 days, worsened for 5 days.
2. Past history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, cor pulmonale, heart failure, and bronchiectasis.
3. Physical examination revealed malnutrition, chronic disease appearance, painful expression, coarse breath sounds in both lungs, and wet and dry rales.
4. SPO2: 70%.
5. Lung CT shows emphysema, bullae, bronchiectasis with obstruction, pleural thickening, and enlarged heart shadow.
reference_diagnosis.treatment:
1. Routine admission, first-level care, and temporary high-salt and low-fat diet.
2. Improve relevant auxiliary inspections.
3. Cardiotonic treatment, diuresis, anti-inflammatory, phlegm-reducing aerosol therapy, improvement of airway function, sodium supplementation, nutrition and symptomatic support treatment.
4. After treatment, the lung function improved, the inflammation was reduced, and the symptoms of heart failure improved, and he was discharged from the hospital a week later.
5. After discharge, it is recommended to continue aerosol treatment, take oral anti-inflammatory drugs, and follow up.

  - Ventricular septal defect (ostium secundum type)
  - Ventricular septal bulge

reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Surgery for atrial septal defect in congenital heart disease
2. Hypertension grade 3 (very high risk)
3. Type 2 diabetes
4. Ischemic cerebrovascular disease and old cerebellar infarction
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. Cardiac ultrasound and esophageal ultrasound show atrial septal defect.
2. Have a history of hypertension for 10 years, with blood pressure controlled at 120-140/70-90mmHg.
3. A 5-year history of diabetes, with blood sugar controlled at 8-10mmol/L (fasting) and 9-12mmol/L (after meals).
4. I had two cerebral infarctions this year and was hospitalized.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After hospitalization, he continued to take aspirin and atorvastatin calcium tablets. Atrial septal defect closure was performed using a 24mm occluder. Intraoperative ultrasound monitored the position of the occluder, which did not affect the heart valves or large blood vessels. The patient recovered well after the operation without any discomfort and was discharged from the hospital 7 days later.

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
#Symptoms#
(1) The patient has a history of two cerebral infarctions, one in April and another in September this year.
(2) The patient has a 10-year history of hypertension, controlled at 120-140/70-90mmHg.
(3) The patient has been diabetic for 5 years, with fasting blood sugar of 8-10mmol/L and postprandial blood sugar of 9-12mmol/L.

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) The patient was diagnosed with an atrial septal defect during a cardiac ultrasound examination 4 years ago.
(2) The patient is currently taking aspirin and atorvastatin calcium tablets after the cerebral infarctions.

#Differential Diagnosis#
(1) Recurrent cerebral infarction due to atrial septal defect
(2) Recurrent cerebral infarction due to hypertension
(3) Recurrent cerebral infarction due to diabetes
(4) Recurrent cerebral infarction due to atherosclerosis
(5) Recurrent cerebral infarction due to a cardiac embolism
(6) Recurrent cerebral infarction due to a hypercoagulable state

#Diagnosis#
Recurrent cerebral infarction due to atrial septal defect

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) The patient has a history of atrial septal defect, which can cause a right-to-left shunt and increase the risk of cerebral infarction.
(2) The patient has a history of hypertension and diabetes, which are risk factors for cerebral infarction. However, the patient's blood pressure and blood sugar levels are controlled, making them less likely to be the primary cause of the recurrent cerebral infarctions.
(3) The patient is currently taking aspirin and atorvastatin calcium tablets, which are commonly used to prevent recurrent cerebral infarctions. However, the patient has still experienced two cerebral infarctions, suggesting that the underlying cause is not being adequately addressed.

#Treatment Plan#
(1) The patient should undergo a repeat cardiac ultrasound to evaluate the size and location of the atrial septal defect and determine if it is causing a right-to-left shunt.
(2) If the atrial septal defect is causing a right-to-left shunt, the patient should be referred to a cardiologist for further evaluation and possible closure of the defect.
(3) The patient should continue taking aspirin and atorvastatin calcium tablets to prevent recurrent cerebral infarctions.
(4) The patient should be closely monitored for any changes in blood pressure or blood sugar levels and should receive appropriate treatment if necessary.
(5) The patient should be encouraged to maintain a healthy lifestyle, including regular exercise, a balanced diet, and avoiding smoking and excessive alcohol consumption.

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient developed weakness in both lower limbs 2 days ago. He can stand but needs support from family members to walk. He is accompanied by dizziness and nausea. His blood pressure was measured at 180/?mmHg. The dizziness was relieved after taking antihypertensive drugs. There was no numbness or abnormal sensation in the limbs. The muscle strength of both upper limbs was good. Normal, no speech disorder, normal bowel movements, no change in weight.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- Head MR: No abnormality found
- Whole spine MRI:
  - C3/4-C6/7 disc herniation
  - Abnormal signal in the spinal cord at T2-4 vertebral level, consider demyelinating disease
  - L3/4, L4/5 intervertebral disc bulge
  - Cervical, thoracic and lumbar bone hyperplasia
- Central nervous system demyelinating disease spectrum (TBA+CBA):
  - cerebrospinal fluid AQP4 1:10, negative for MOG and GFAP
  - Serum AQP4 1:100, negative for MOG and GFAP
- Evoked potential:
  - Bilateral VEP: No waveform is seen on the left side, normal on the right side
  - Normal bilateral BAEP
  - SEP of both lower limbs: poor differentiation of cortical potential and prolonged latency
  - Normal SEP of both upper limbs
- Cerebrospinal fluid examination:
  - Pressure 120mmH20
  - Colorless and transparent
  - Total number of cells 40x10^6/L
  - White blood cell count 40x10^6/L
  - Protein 0.65g/L
  - Lactic acid 2.9mmol/L
  - Adenosine deaminase 1.2U/L
  - Blood adenosine deaminase 7U/L
  - Ink stain, Gram stain negative
- Blood sugar during the same period: 7.8mmol/L
- Electrolyte: Magnesium 0.73↓mmol/L, the remainder is normal
- cerebrospinal fluid cytology: abnormal, mainly lymphocytes
- Electromyography of the limbs: multiple peripheral nerve abnormalities, demyelination and axonal damage in the right lower limb
- Serum + cerebrospinal fluid oligoclonal band (OB): positive, type I, OB is only seen in CSF
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: Neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder
reference_diagnosis.basis: The patient was female. She had a history of optic nerve atrophy leading to blindness in her left eye. The acute onset of the disease was weakness of both lower limbs. Auxiliary examination showed abnormal spinal MRI signals, abnormal evoked potentials, and positive AQP4 antibodies in the cerebrospinal fluid, which met the diagnostic criteria for AQP4-lgG positive NMOSD.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After thorough examination after admission, the patient was diagnosed as NMOSD according to the "Chinese Guidelines for the Diagnosis and Treatment of Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Diseases (2021)". Treatment included intravenous methylprednisolone immunomodulation, step reduction, oral prednisone, potassium chloride, and methylprednisolone. Lazole and calcium carbonate D3 tablets are used to prevent hormonal side effects, and mycophenolate mofetil is used for immunosuppressive treatment. Symptoms were relieved, vital signs were stable, and discharge standards were met.

(5) Good muscle strength in the upper limbs
(6) No speech disorders
(7) Normal bowel movements
(8) No changes in weight
(9) Blind in the left eye for more than 10 years
(10) Diabetes for 7 years

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Blood sugar: 7.8mmol/L
(2) Electrolyte: Magnesium 0.73↓mmol/L, the remainder is normal
(3) Head MR: No abnormality found
(4) Whole spine MRI:

* C3/4-C6/7 disc herniation
* Abnormal signal in the spinal cord at T2-4 vertebral level, consider demyelinating disease
* L3/4, L4/5 intervertebral disc bulge
* Cervical, thoracic and lumbar bone hyperplasia

(5) Nerve conduction studies:

* Total number of cells 40x10^6/L
* White blood cell count 40x10^6/L

#Diagnosis#

#Diagnostic Basis#

(2) Positive oligoclonal band in the cerebrospinal fluid
(3) Multiple peripheral nerve abnormalities, demyelination and axonal damage in the right lower limb

#Treatment Plan#

(4) Encourage the patient to maintain a healthy lifestyle, including regular exercise, a balanced diet, and adequate sleep
(5) Provide education and support to the patient and their family to help them understand and manage the disease.

(2) Medications, such as nitrates, beta-blockers, or calcium channel blockers, to relieve symptoms and prevent angina attacks.
(3) Regular follow-up appointments to monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as needed.

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient developed fever and cough without obvious triggers on January 30, 2021, and went to a local hospital. After anti-infective treatment, the symptoms were not relieved, and routine blood tests showed that the white blood cell count continued to increase and the hemoglobin decreased. Further examination revealed that chest CT showed infectious lesions in the left lower lung, bone marrow aspiration showed active proliferation, an increased proportion of blast cells, and flow cytometry detected abnormal myeloid phenotype immature cells.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- Blood routine:
  - White blood cell count: 47.51x10^9/L (increased)
  - Hemoglobin: 75g/L (decreased)
  - Platelet count: 188x10^9/L
- Inflammation markers:
  - C-reactive protein: 101.5mg/L (increased)
- Coagulation:
  - Procalcitonin activity: 65% (decreased)
  - Prothrombin time: 14.7s (extended)
  - International Normalized Ratio: 574mg/dL (elevated)
  - Fibrin degradation products: 17.6ug/ml (increased)
- Virus screening: negative
- Biochemical tests:
  - Electrolytes, liver and kidney function: no obvious abnormalities
- Film degree exam:
  - Chest CT: Infectious lesions in the left lower lung
  - Cardiac ultrasound: left ventricular ejection fraction 61.18%, no obvious abnormalities in intracardiac structure and blood flow
  - Abdominal ultrasound: The spleen is enlarged and can reach 1.2cm under the ribs
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: Acute myeloid leukemia (high-risk type)
reference_diagnosis.basis: The patient was a young male with acute onset. Blood routine showed an increase in white blood cells. Bone marrow puncture showed that the proportion of blast cells was 37.5%. Flow cytometry detected abnormal myeloid phenotype blast cells occupying 15.58% of nucleated cells and expressing CD34st, CD117st, CD38, etc. , some cells express CD36, HLADR, CD81, but do not express CD33, CD7, CD10, etc., which meet the diagnostic criteria for acute myeloid leukemia.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After the patient was admitted to hospital, he was given anti-infective treatment and his fever was relieved, but the blood routine showed that the white blood cell count was still elevated. Bone marrow genetic testing showed increased expression of WT1 and EVI1, and negative FLT3-TD and NPM1 mutations. The bone marrow morphology showed active proliferation and the proportion of blasts was 50%. NGS testing revealed FLT3-TKD and TP53 germline mutations. The patient received HAA regimen chemotherapy and developed gastrointestinal reactions during chemotherapy, which improved after symptomatic treatment. Bone marrow flow cytometry showed that BCL-2 positive cells accounted for 23.05%. Bone marrow chromosomal testing revealed abnormalities. The patient developed a pulmonary infection during the bone marrow suppression period. After antibacterial treatment, the infection improved and his blood count returned to normal.

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
#Symptoms#
(1) Fever and cough for more than 10 days
(2) No history of special diseases

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Routine blood tests showed an increase in white blood cell count and a decrease in hemoglobin
(2) Chest CT scan revealed infectious lesions in the left lower lung
(3) Bone marrow aspiration showed active proliferation and an increased proportion of blast cells
(4) Flow cytometry detected abnormal myeloid phenotype immature cells

#Diagnosis#
Acute myeloid leukemia (AML)

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) The patient's symptoms of fever and cough for more than 10 days, along with the results of the routine blood tests, suggest an underlying hematological disorder.
(2) The presence of infectious lesions in the left lower lung on the chest CT scan, active proliferation and an increased proportion of blast cells in the bone marrow aspiration, and the detection of abnormal myeloid phenotype immature cells by flow cytometry are all consistent with a diagnosis of AML.

#Treatment Plan#
(1) The patient should be referred to a hematologist for further evaluation and management.
(2) The treatment plan for AML typically involves chemotherapy, which may be followed by a stem cell transplant.
(3) The patient should also receive supportive care, including antibiotics to prevent infections, blood transfusions to maintain adequate blood counts, and pain management as needed.
(4) The patient should be closely monitored for complications and side effects of treatment.

Please note that this is a preliminary diagnosis based on the information provided, and further testing and evaluation may be necessary to confirm the diagnosis and determine the best course of treatment.

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient began to experience chest tightness and shortness of breath 1 year ago, with occasional palpitations and no chest pain. He was treated at Shanghai No. 7 People's Hospital. Coronary angiography showed 30% stenosis, and he was diagnosed with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. He was treated with aspirin and metoprolol. In November 2019, he was hospitalized due to chest tightness, shortness of breath and cough. Echocardiography showed LVEF 40%, left atrial diameter increase, left ventricular enlargement with weakened ventricular wall contraction, mild tricuspid valve and aortic valve regurgitation, and he was diagnosed with dilated myocardium. sick. Recently, the symptoms worsened after stopping the medication, with dry cough, no chest pain, and no fever. Emergency echocardiography showed enlargement of the whole heart, reduced systolic activity of the left ventricular wall, and mild aortic regurgitation. The electrocardiogram showed sinus tachycardia, premature ventricular tachycardia, and intraventricular conduction block. Other examinations including lung CT, blood routine, and serum potassium were all abnormal.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- Lung CT
  - Chronic inflammation of the right lung with partial organizing changes
  - Multiple mildly enlarged lymph nodes in the mediastinum
  - Mild enlargement of the heart, mainly left ventricular enlargement
- Echocardiography
  - Whole heart enlargement (LA49mm, LVDD67mm)
  - The overall systolic activity of the left ventricular wall was significantly reduced (LVEF37%)
  - Mild aortic regurgitation
- EKG
  - Sinus tachycardia (116 beats/min)
  - Room breakfast
  - Intraventricular block (QRS132ms)
- Blood routine
  - No abnormality
- Blood chemistry
  - TnI0.153ng/ml
  - Serum potassium 4.21mmol/l
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Dilated cardiomyopathy, sinus tachycardia, arrhythmia: intraventricular conduction block, cardiac function class III (NYHA)
2. Hypertension grade 3, very high risk
reference_diagnosis.basis: The patient had repeated chest tightness and shortness of breath, echocardiography showed decreased left ventricular function, and electrocardiogram showed tachycardia and arrhythmia, consistent with the diagnosis of dilated cardiomyopathy. He had a history of hypertension and irregular blood pressure control. Based on the increase in blood pressure and risk factors, he was diagnosed with grade 3 hypertension, which is very high risk.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After admission, ECG monitoring, low-salt and low-fat diet, blood pressure monitoring, bed rest, anti-platelet aggregation treatment, blood pressure control, heart failure treatment, diuresis and hypokalemia prevention treatment, and myocardial nutrition were given. He was discharged after his condition stabilized.

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
#Symptoms#
(1) Recurrent chest tightness and shortness of breath for more than a year, worsening over the past three days.
(2) Occasional palpitations but no chest pain.
(3) Dry cough but no fever.
(4) History of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and hypertension.
(5) Non-compliance with medication.

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Electrocardiogram (ECG) to check heart's electrical activity and rhythm.
(2) Echocardiogram to assess the structure and function of the heart.
(3) Chest X-ray to check for signs of heart failure, pneumonia, or other lung conditions.
(4) Blood tests to check for signs of infection, heart failure, or other conditions.
(5) Pulmonary function tests to assess lung function.

#Diagnosis#
Worsening of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy due to non-compliance with medication, leading to heart failure.

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Symptoms of chest tightness, shortness of breath, and occasional palpitations, which have worsened over the past three days.
(2) History of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and hypertension.
(3) Non-compliance with medication.
(4) Results of ECG, echocardiogram, chest X-ray, blood tests, and pulmonary function tests.

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Resume taking medication as prescribed (aspirin and metoprolol).
(2) Consider additional medication to manage heart failure symptoms, such as diuretics or ACE inhibitors.
(3) Lifestyle modifications, such as a low-sodium diet, regular exercise, and stress management.
(4) Regular follow-up appointments with a cardiologist to monitor heart function and adjust treatment as needed.
(5) Avoid activities that may worsen symptoms, such as strenuous exercise or heavy lifting.

reference_diagnosis.symptom: Six years ago, the patient had dull pain in the right hypochondrium, accompanied by swelling and discomfort in the shoulder and back. He was diagnosed with hepatitis B, and abdominal ultrasound showed fatty liver. After antiviral treatment with entecavir, the symptoms were relieved and he has been taking the medicine ever since. One month ago, the discomfort in the right hypochondrium worsened, and he lost about ten pounds. Ultrasound at another hospital found a medium-high echo mass in the liver, which was considered a liver mass. He came to our hospital for further diagnosis and treatment.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- Imaging examination
- Abdominal ultrasound: intrahepatic medium-high echo mass.
- Upper abdominal enhanced MRI: 5.5*6cm space-occupying lesion in the left lobe of the liver, hepatocellular carcinoma is considered; mild cirrhosis; multiple small and slightly enlarged lymph nodes in the hepatogastric space and retroperitoneum.
- Laboratory examination
- Liver function: Alanine aminotransferase 61U/L increased, aspartate aminotransferase 42U/L increased, alkaline phosphatase 98U/L normal, glutamyl transpeptidase 52U/L normal, total bilirubin 8.9umol/L normal, albumin 48.5g/L normal, total cholesterol 3.49mmol/L normal, triglyceride 1.17mmol/L normal, high-density lipoprotein 0.81mmol/L decreased.
- Tumor markers: AFP 5.46ug/L normal, carcinoembryonic antigen, carbohydrate antigen CA199 normal.
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: Hepatocellular carcinoma stage T1bN0M0IB, cirrhosis
reference_diagnosis.basis:
① He has a history of hepatitis B for six years and has been taking entecavir for a long time.
② I have recently experienced discomfort in my right flank and lost weight.
③ Ultrasound and magnetic resonance examination showed space-occupying lesions in the left lobe of the liver, suggesting hepatocellular carcinoma and cirrhosis.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: The patient had a history of hepatitis B for six years, and recently had discomfort in the right ribs and weight loss. After admission, a detailed examination was conducted. He was diagnosed with liver cancer and cirrhosis. Imaging showed no distant metastasis and was suitable for surgical treatment. Relevant examinations and preparations were performed before surgery, including hepatic artery chemotherapy drug perfusion embolization. Fever and abnormal liver function occurred after surgery, which improved after anti-infection and liver protection treatment. Two weeks after surgery, the tumor shrank to 5*4cm, and laparoscopic left lateral hepatectomy was performed. Postoperative pathology confirmed hepatocellular carcinoma, moderately differentiated, with a tumor size of 4.5*5.0*2.8cm, and no residual liver capsule or stump cancer tissue. The postoperative evaluation was T1bN0M0IB stage. Anti-infection, liver protection, and stomach protection treatments were given after surgery. After discharge, continue to take entecavir and have regular follow-up.

#Auxiliary Examinations#

#Diagnosis#
Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) The patient has a history of hepatitis B and fatty liver, which are risk factors for HCC.
(2) The patient has been experiencing right flank discomfort for more than a month, and an ultrasound found a liver mass.
(3) The patient has lost about ten pounds, which may be a sign of cancer-related weight loss.

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Further imaging tests such as a CT scan or MRI to evaluate the liver mass and determine its size, location, and extent.
(2) A biopsy of the liver mass to confirm the diagnosis and determine the stage of the cancer.
(3) Depending on the stage of the cancer, treatment options may include surgery, liver transplantation, radiofrequency ablation, or chemotherapy.
(4) The patient should continue taking entecavir to manage their hepatitis B and prevent further liver damage.
(5) The patient should be monitored closely for any changes in their symptoms or liver function.

He could lift his upper limbs and walk his lower limbs, but the numbness in his hands and feet worsened and gradually spread upward. There was no speech impairment, convulsions, difficulty breathing, or loss of consciousness. The symptoms worsened 1 day ago, causing difficulty in lifting the upper limbs and walking in the lower limbs. No abnormality was found in the outpatient brain CT examination. During the course of the disease, his diet was poor, his sleep was normal, and his bowel movements were good.

reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: acute Guillain-Barre syndrome
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. Young male with recent history of cold
2. Complaints of numbness and weakness in limbs, which have worsened recently
3. Physical examination revealed that the muscle strength of the limbs dropped to level 2
4. Nerve conduction velocity examination suggests peripheral nerve damage
reference_diagnosis.treatment:
After diagnosis of acute Guillain-Barré syndrome, the patient received the following treatments:
- Methylcobalamin injection 0.5mg, intravenous drip, once a day for 7 days
- Vitamin B1 tablet 10mg, taken orally, once a day for 8 days
- Adenosine triphosphate disodium injection 20 mg, intravenous drip, once a day for 5 days
- Methylprednisolone injection 240mg, intravenous drip, once a day for 3 days
- Methylprednisolone injection 120mg, intravenous drip, once a day for a total of 3 days
- Methylprednisolone injection 40mg, intravenous drip, once a day for 3 days
- Gamma globulin injection 28g, intravenous drip, once a day for a total of 5 days
After treatment, the symptoms were relieved, the limb weakness improved, and the vital signs were stable, meeting the conditions for discharge. After discharge, patients are advised to eat a balanced diet, undergo rehabilitation treatment, and undergo regular review.

#Symptoms#
(1) Numbness and weakness in limbs for the past 4 days, starting after a cold.
(2) Difficulty lifting upper limbs and walking with lower limbs, worsening 1 day ago.

(4) Normal diet, sleep, and bowel movements.

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Outpatient brain CT examination: No abnormalities found.
(2) ECG, blood pressure, and blood oxygen saturation monitoring: Normal.

#Diagnosis#
Guillain-Barré Syndrome

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Symptoms of progressive weakness and numbness in the limbs, starting after a cold.
(2) No abnormalities found in brain CT examination.
(3) Normal ECG, blood pressure, and blood oxygen saturation monitoring.

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) therapy: This is a common treatment for Guillain-Barré Syndrome and can help reduce the severity and duration of symptoms.
(2) Physical therapy: This can help maintain muscle strength and flexibility, and prevent muscle atrophy.
(3) Pain management: Pain medication may be prescribed to help manage any discomfort or pain associated with the condition.
(4) Monitoring: Regular monitoring of symptoms and vital signs will be necessary to ensure the effectiveness of treatment and to prevent any complications.

Please note that this diagnosis and treatment plan is based on the information provided and may need to be adjusted based on further testing and evaluation. It is important to consult with a healthcare professional for a definitive diagnosis and treatment plan.

After emergency treatment, brain MRI showed multiple recent lacunar infarcts, and echocardiography revealed a patent foramen ovale. The patient received antiplatelet, lipid-lowering, and nutritional cranial nerve therapy. No dizziness, headache, chest tightness and shortness of breath, abdominal pain and distension, nausea and vomiting. He eats well, sleeps normally, has normal bowel movements, and has no significant change in weight.

  - 2022-10-03 Brain CT scan: No abnormal density changes were found.

  - 2022-10-10 Brain MRA: The right posterior communicating artery is open.
- Cardiac imaging tests:
  - 2022-10-10 Transesophageal three-dimensional cardiac ultrasound + graphic report: Patent foramen ovale, tunnel length is about 7.8mm.
  - 2022-10-10 Cardiac contrast-enhanced ultrasound: Patent foramen ovale, a large number of microbubbles in the left heart after right heart imaging.
- Other imaging tests:

reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Congenital heart disease, patent foramen ovale, patent foramen ovale closure after surgery
2. Multiple cerebral infarction
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. Echocardiography and transesophageal three-dimensional cardiac ultrasound show patent foramen ovale.
2. Brain MRI showed multiple recent lacunar infarcts in the subcortical area of ​​the right temporal lobe, the subcortical area of ​​the right frontal lobe, and the right center semiovale.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: The patient underwent interventional patent foramen ovale closure. Postoperative cardiac ultrasound showed that the closure effect was good and the left ventricular diastolic function was normal. The patient's symptoms improved and he was discharged.

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
#Symptoms#
(1) Numbness in fingers for over a month
(2) Recent episode of slurred speech lasting for about a minute

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Patent foramen ovale diagnosis
(2) Multiple recent lacunar infarcts diagnosis

#Diagnosis#
Cryptogenic stroke with patent foramen ovale

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Presence of patent foramen ovale, which can be a source of emboli leading to stroke
(2) Multiple recent lacunar infarcts, indicating a history of cerebrovascular events

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Continue antiplatelet therapy to prevent further clot formation
(2) Continue lipid-lowering therapy to manage cholesterol levels and reduce the risk of future strokes
(3) Consider percutaneous closure of the patent foramen ovale, depending on the size and associated risks
(4) Regular follow-ups with a neurologist and cardiologist to monitor progress and adjust treatment as needed
(5) Encourage lifestyle modifications, such as regular exercise, a balanced diet, and smoking cessation, to reduce the risk of future strokes.

reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: Acute cholecystitis, gallbladder stones, dyslipidemia
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. Abdominal pain for 4 days, upper abdominal cramping and then spread to the whole abdomen.
2. Past history of gallbladder stones.
3. Auxiliary examinations showed elevated C-reactive protein, mildly elevated amylase and lipase, abnormal blood lipids, and ultrasound and CT showed gallstones accompanied by cholecystitis.
reference_diagnosis.treatment:
1. After thorough examination after admission, CRP was elevated, transaminases and bilirubin were normal, and ultrasound and CT showed gallstones accompanied by cholecystitis.
2. For treatment, a liquid diet, pantoprazole 20 mg once every two days for acid suppression, piperacillin-tazobactam 4.5 g every 12 hours for intravenous anti-infection, and fluid rehydration were given for 5 days.
3. The patient's abdominal pain is relieved and there is no nausea or vomiting. It is recommended that he and hepatobiliary surgery be further diagnosed and treated after discharge to evaluate the indications for cholecystectomy.

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient has developed symptoms such as fatigue, palpitation, and dizziness since December 27, 2020, accompanied by tinnitus. The symptoms worsened after activity. The physical examination at the unit revealed abnormal blood routine, but no attention was paid to it. Subsequently, the symptoms gradually worsened, accompanied by gum swelling and pain, and low-grade fever. Routine blood tests showed a decrease in white blood cells and hemoglobin, and bone marrow examination showed acute myeloid leukemia. After chemotherapy, the symptoms improved and the blood count recovered. Repeat bone marrow examination showed disease remission.

  - Cardiac enzymes: no abnormality
  - Echocardiogram: no abnormality
  - Electrocardiogram: no abnormality

  - Biochemistry: No obvious abnormality
  - Coagulation: No obvious abnormality

reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML-M5)
reference_diagnosis.basis: The patient presented with fatigue and palpitation. Routine blood tests showed leukopenia and anemia. Bone marrow examination showed that immature monocytes accounted for 92.5%. Bone marrow flow cytometry showed that abnormal myeloid immature cells accounted for 94.50%. Chromosome karyotype analysis showed complex The karyotype is consistent with the diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia (M5).
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After admission, the patient underwent lumbar puncture and intrathecal injection for preventive treatment, and no abnormalities were found in cerebrospinal fluid examination. Then the medium-dose Ara-C regimen chemotherapy was started. The treatment process went smoothly, no obvious adverse reactions were seen, and the patient was discharged after his vital signs stabilized.

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient developed pain and weakness in both lower limbs without obvious triggers 3 months ago. The upper limbs moved normally and the lower limbs needed help to walk. He was accompanied by numbness in the limbs and had no speech impairment or convulsions. Brain CT examination revealed bilateral lacunar cerebral infarction. The symptoms worsened half a month before admission, but his sleep and diet were acceptable.

- Neuroimaging examination
  - Brain CT: Bilateral lacunar infarction
  - Whole spine MRI: space-occupying lesions in the spinal canal
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: ependymoma
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. Pain and weakness in both lower limbs for 3 months, worsening recently
2. No history of hypertension or diabetes
3. Physical examination revealed that the muscle strength of both lower limbs was level 3.
4. Whole-spine MRI shows space-occupying lesions in the spinal canal
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After the patient was admitted to the hospital, a whole-spine MRI was performed, and he was diagnosed with ependymoma. Lumbar spinal decompression and resection of extramedullary subdural lesions were performed. After surgery, methylcobalamin, citicoline, piperacillin sodium, tazobactam sodium and compound amino acid injection were given for treatment. Symptoms were relieved, vital signs were stable, and discharge standards were met. The patient was instructed to continue rehabilitation treatment and undergo regular review after discharge.

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient developed chest tightness, shortness of breath, and occasional palpitations after exerting himself 6 months ago, but the symptoms resolved spontaneously. Symptoms have worsened in the past week, accompanied by fatigue and decreased activity tolerance. There was no syncope, nausea, vomiting, or precordial pain. The electrocardiogram from another hospital showed atrial fibrillation, and the ejection fraction on cardiac color Doppler ultrasound was 35%. The patient was given coronary enlargement, anti-platelet, lipid-lowering, and anti-heart failure treatments in the outpatient clinic. However, the symptoms persisted, so he was admitted to the hospital. There was no fever, cough, sputum production, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea or lower limb edema. He can eat well, has normal bowel movements, and has no significant change in weight.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- blood test:
  -NT-ProBNP: 404.20 pg/mL
- Echocardiography:
  - Left atrial diameter: 58×50 mm
  - Inner diameter of right atrium: 51×45 mm

  - Aortic valve degeneration

reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Alcoholic cardiomyopathy and cardiac insufficiency (cardiac function class II)
2. Cardiac arrhythmia atrial fibrillation
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. The patient has a history of smoking and drinking, chest tightness, shortness of breath, and cardiac color ultrasound ejection fraction of 35%.
2. Physical examination showed irregular heartbeat, varying heart sounds, and electrocardiogram showed atrial fibrillation.
3. The patient has risk factors for coronary heart disease and has chest tightness and shortness of breath after activity. Coronary heart disease cannot be ruled out.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After admission, the patient was given treatment to reduce the preload and postload of the heart, including recombinant human natriuretic peptide, furosemide, spironolactone, sacubitril valsartan, dapagliflozin, metoprolol succinate, aspirin, clopidogrel, and rivaroxaban. Coronary CTA showed no stenosis. Considering alcoholic cardiomyopathy, dual anti-antibody was stopped, and anti-heart failure treatment was continued. Before discharge, EF increased to 54%, and the diagnosis was revised to alcoholic cardiomyopathy.

Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) secondary to alcoholic cardiomyopathy.

#Treatment Plan#

(3) Consider referral to a cardiologist for further management and follow-up.
(4) Consider referral to a cardiac rehabilitation program to improve exercise tolerance and quality of life.
(5) Consider referral to a nutritionist for dietary counseling to optimize heart health.
(6) Consider referral to a psychologist or support group for alcohol cessation counseling.

6. If the patient has other neurological disorders, further evaluation will be needed to determine the cause and appropriate treatment.
